div4.head: Obituaries.
div4.p: Killed, in the Richmond battle of Tuesday evening, July 1st, 1862, Robert W. Y. Newport, aged 25 years, a native of East Baton Rouge parish. La., and First Lieutenant of Company C. 7th regiment Louisiana volunteers.
In the same action, Edmond E. Leblanc, aged 23 years, a native of Attakapas, La., and First Lieutenant of Company C, 8th regiment Louisiana volunteers.

Many brave and noble spirits have of late sealed their devotion to the cause of the Confederacy with their life's blood, but none braver or noble than the subjects of this notice.
LeBlanc I had known only since the organization of the 8th regiment of Louisiana volunteers, more than twelve months since, and in that time I learnt to love and appreciate him. Always courteous, always affable and kind, he made friends of all who came in contact with him. Stirring and energetic, strict when the line of duty required it, and gentle and friendly to every man when off service, he was deservedly ranked amongst the best officers of his regiment and brigade.
Through severe indisposition he was necessarily absent from his regiment and company during a great portion of its glorious career in the campaign of Gen. Jackson in the Valley of Virginia; and on his return to duty, when yet suffering some what from the malady that had detained him, much against his will, from scenes he ardently desired witnessing, he was fired by a noble ambition to so act as to more than compensate for his forced absence.
On the bloody field of Friday, June 27th he behaved, as all his friends knew he would, Handsomely and gallantly, and in the fight of the ensuing Tuesday evening he fell, where duty called him, in front of his company, fearlessly breasting the enemy's missives of death.
All honor and respect, then, to the memory of that brave Louisianian, one of the first who answered his country's call for troops!

Newport was a companion of my boyhood, a college-mate for two years, and an intimate, reliable, and well-beloved friend to the very moment of his death.
Were I to say all in his praise that inclination bids me say, I might be considered as too fulsome; but, after all, I would only have been doing justice to a friend, and one, too, towards whom even partiality would be excusable.
His home was my home whenever I chose to make it, and whenever 'twas-in his power to aid and assist he did so unasked, and from the pure inspirations of his friendly heart.
All this of course endeared him to me, and I reciprocated his kindnesses as well as I could, and as it was with me, so it was with others.
From my perfect acquaintance with him, I can most truthfully affirm that no young man of his parish stood higher in general estimation.
In the four-fold capacities of friend, college-mate, fellow-parishioner, and fellow-soldier, he always stood well, I know.
At the breaking out of the war he was most profitably engaged with his aged father in the management of a large unencumbered cotton estate, but this he readily abandoned to offer his services to his country.
As a simple private he became one of the Baton Rouge Fencibles, the fourth volunteer company raised in his parish, which went into Col. Hays's 7th regiment of Louisiana volunteers as company "B," At the battle of Manassas, Newport, still a private, was in the front ranks of his company, and shared in all the glories of the charge of the 7th against the insolent foe near the close of the battle, when that regiment and other regiments of Gen. Early's brigade, to which the 7th was then attached, gave McDowell's grand army its coup de grace. I have often heard Newport's officers express themselves in the highest terms of his conduct as a private — how well and cheerfully one, accustomed to all the luxuries and comforts of a home of wealth and abundance, bore the privations and discomforts of the private's camp life.
Last November he was elected 2d Lieutenant, Jr., of the Sarsfield Rangers, company "C" of his regiment, a properly bestowed mark of appreciation.
But before this occurred, Newport gave a most striking evidence of his worth as a man and Southern soldier.

During the fall elections of Louisiana, a host of friends brought out his name as a candidate for a seat in the State Legislature, and though his chances of election were good, he modestly declined the proffered honor, alleging his preference to remain where he was — a simple soldier of the Army of the Potomac.
Noble and patriotic conduct, such as might have been expected of New port, and most worthy of imitation!

In December he became Second Lieutenant of his company; and in April, First Lieutenant, the position he held when killed.
He had gone, unharmed and unscratched, through eight battles; but in the ninth, as fated, he fell.
Besides Manassas, at Front Royal, Middletown, Winchester, Cotton Farm, Cross Keys, Port Republic, and Coal Harbor, he was one of "the bravest of the brave," who fought well and successfully, and came out of the fiery ordeals unscathed.
At Port Republic the 7th Louisiana regiment lost no less than 162 men, killed and wounded, out of 380 men engaged; but Newport, though throughout in the thickest of the fray, was not of those lost.
Providence reserved him for another field, and 'twas on Tuesday evening, in his ninth battle, as I have already stated, that the gallant young hero fell, and then nigh unto the close of the engagement.
Night had already thrown her mantle over the scene of strife, and the combatants were only guiding themselves by the flash of the guns, when Newport received the death- carrying ball in his head, which must have killed him instantly.
Five minutes more of successful strife and he would have lived, for then the conflict ended.
In the morning his body was found not more than two hundred miles away managed Yankee battery missiles at the ranks's morning that Yankee battery and the were gone, and my poor dead friend

passed the first night of his long, last sleep upon a field of victory occupied by Western soldiers, his dead body one of the nearest to the spot where the enemy's guns had last opened upon our troops.

To Newport's aged father and to his doting mother his loss must be almost as a crushing blow, for he was their only, their dearly beloved son. But in view of the glorious manner of his death, and the greatness and sacredness of the cause for which he died, with fortitude becoming the Southern patriot and the Souther matron, in these days of trial and tribulation, and with Christian resignation, they will hear their great, their in calculable misfortune.
He lies buried by a church, less than a mile from where he was killed, and near him also lies the gallant LeBlanc, and their names are now added to those of Seymour, DeChoiseul, McArthur, Wheat, Smith, Nicholas, and a sadly long list of brave men, whose untimely ends the Louisiana brigade now mourn. A. L. G.
Baton Rouge Advocate (now published at Opelousas, La.) please copy.

One of the noblest and bravest sons of the South who fell in Tuesday's battle in front of Richmond, was Wm. L. Anderson, aged 38 years, of Culpeper county, Va., a member of Company B, 13th Virginia regiment.
After having fought most valiantly nearly through the battle, he was struck, as I have been informed, by a grapeshot about 9 o'clock P. M., from the severe wounds of which he lingered until Thursday morning. His wife, living at Culpeper Court-House, hearing soon after the battle that he was slightly wounded, instantly repaired to this city to minister to his sufferings, and in a few days, as she hoped, to accompany him to their home.
But, alas!
on her arrival here she was met by the soul-afflicting and unexpected tidings that her husband was no more.
Already a friend or two, who remained with him during his sufferings, had deposited his remains in the garden, or yard, near the dwelling-house on the farm where the battle was fought, and appropriately designated the spot.
What a shock was this to her, a lady of delicate health, a nervous system already greatly enfeebled and impaired during the last twelve months by the deaths of a son and daughter, lovely and promising children!
How inscrutable are the judgments of God!

The subject of this notice was a faithful soldier during the campaign of last summer and much of the winter.
His term of service having expired, he spent some time with his family, but soon re-enlisted, and his company was ordered to Gen. Jackson's command in the Valley.
Before leaving home, standing with his wife near the graves of his children, he said to her: "Martha, I never expect to see you again.
If I make my grave over the mountains, have my body brought, if you can, and laid by the side of our children" He fought gallantly through the battles of the Valley, and marched to the Peninsula to strike his last blow in defence of liberty, family, and country.

The writer of this notice had an opportunity of knowing Mr. Anderson well, having boarded in his family a portion of two years. He was a firm believer in, though not a professor of religion.
In letters to his wife he would say, in substance, "I never go into an engagement without committing myself to the care of God.
I have an abiding confidence in His mercy." The tone of his letters was frequently pious and devotional.
To naturally a higher order of talent than is given to most men, he added no small degree of intellectual culture and polish.
His was the strictest integrity.
None excelled him in honesty and uprightness of principle.
Always ready to do acts of kindness, he was an obliging neighbor, affectionate husband, and devoted father.
The God of all grace and consolation sustain and comfort the deeply distressed widow, and bless the fatherless and sorrowing children.
P.
Richmond Christian Advocate please copy.

Was killed on Tuesday, the 1st of July, in the battle below Richmond, Nicholas W. Dawson, a member of Company D, 12th regiment Virginia volunteers.
He fell while serving his country in the discharge of duty.
This brave and generous-hearted young man was a son of Daniel Dawson, for many years a resident of Richmond, Va.; his son responded cheerfully and patriotically to the first call made by his glorious old mother State, shouldered his musket, and in the bloom of youth took his leave of an affectionate old father, mother, one brother, and two beloved sisters, who bitterly mourn this early separation; but in spite of all their cries and tears, this youthful soldier took up his line of march to share his fare in a war imposed upon honest people.
Poor fellow, farewell!
The storm of your last battle has ceased.
On the field no trace will shortly remain that you ever lived; the worms will devour your flesh, and the mound raised over your grave will sink back to the common level with the plain.
But can this mournful story be read by the fathers, mothers, sons, and daughters, of Southern freedom, without wringing tears of blood from their hearts?
I am proud to say of this heroic and daring youth, never was any soldier more willing to discharge his duty.
He left home at the age of twenty-one, and entered the battle-field, where he now sweetly sleeps in peace.
He leaves a pious father and mother, one brother, and two beloved sisters, to mourn their loss.
Peace be to the remains of him who so bravely lost his life in the defence of his country.
His end has been a noble one, in a just cause; he became a victim to a just God; he has gone full of hope and immortality.
We shall ever cherish with fond remembrance the many virtues of our dear young friend.

lg.l: No useless coffin confined his breast,
Nor in sheet, or shroud they bound him:
But he lay like a warrior taking his rest,
With his martial cloak around him.
Slowly and sadly they laid him down,
From the field of his fame, fresh and gory;
They carved not a line, they raised not a stone;
But they left him alone in his glory.

At the residence of his father, in the county of Prince Edward, on the 10th of June, J. Goodrich Ligon, of the Prince Edward troop.
Just one year ago he left his home, its sweets, its pleasures, sundered the ties which bound him to his family and to his friends, to aid in driving the ruthless invader from the land of his birth.
For twelve months he endured the hardships and faced the dangers of a soldier's life, in a manner which won for him the high approval of his officers, the esteem and confidence of each of his comrades.
By his generosity, amiability, gentleness, kindness, and piety, he endeared himself to all. Prostrate from exertions in the cause of freedom, he reached his home, and, after an illness of thirteen days, passed from time to eternity, from the gloom of earth to the glory of Heaven.
In his death, his family has lost an endeared son, an affectionate brother; his troop a valuable member, his country a brave soldier.
But one month ago we bid him farewell, hoping, as we did, that the comforts of his home and the attentions of his friends would recruit him sufficiently to resume the labors of a soldier.
Alas! how often our hopes deceive us. He has fallen a martyr to liberty.
We weep not as those without hope, for we have reason to trust and believe that he has been but removed from this vale of tears to that bright world above, where redeemed spirits will ever bask in the sunlight from a Saviour's face.
"Rest, soldier, thy warfare is o'er." Fresh live his memory as the grass above his grave. R. B.
Camp near Richmond, July 8th.
Died, suddenly, on the 17th of June, 1862, at Wellington, Northampton county, Va., in the 63d year of her age, Mrs. Margaret S. Bayly, widow of John H. Bayly, Esq., deceased.

The above brief sentence records the last on earth of one of the noblest creatures of God.
It tells us that another should, too good for earth, has taken its everlasting flight to Heaven, and that death has removed from a sorrowing household and fireside a beloved mother, sister, and friend; for "none knew her but to love her, none named her but to praise." Truly, Providence has seen fit to afflict us heavily — almost more than we can bear.
Our loss is yet too great to realise.
Seven months ago our homes and firesides were invaded by the vile minions of a despot, and her only son was forced to leave her, or be consigned to a Yankee prison.
He was one of the main supports and comforts of her old age, and from the time he was driven from her trouble and sorrow began their work on a mind that had always been happy and cheerful.
Her health and strength daily declined, and we are now mourning an idolized mother, the kindest of sisters, and the best of friends.
We mourn her with melting hearts, and will cherish her memory forever.
We have one comfort: we feel that she has gone "where the wicked cease from troubling and the weary are at rest." C. S.

Captain Dennis Vermillion, of the Old Dominion Guards, 9th Va. Reg't, fell, July 1st, gallantly leading his men to victory.
As the deadly missile struck his breast he was cheering forth, all weak and wounded, a last word of encouragement.
Suddenly, in the pride of his manhood, in the first flush of glory, he died a true soldier's death on the field.
Young and ardent, he left a tender wife just as life was opening in fairest vista before them.--Ah, sad to think!
how all unconscious she tells the two babes of his coming who will never more return.
As modest as he was brave, he won respect and affection from all associated with him. He was too well content with the daily conscientious discharge of duty, and too unpretending, to covet any conspicuous blazonry of his deeds; yet he has left an unfading memorial of himself in the hearts of his comrades and friends, which they will keep over green with their tears.
Let us emulate his many virtues, and he rightly admonished by his early fate. T.

At the General Hospital, in this city, on Saturday morning, July the 5th, from wounds received in the engagement of the 30th of June William A. Tugule, of Company F, (Farmville Guards) 18th regiment Virginia volunteers, aged twenty-seven years and six months.

Poor William! he has been taken from us to swell the list of heroic martyr in the cause of freedom.
No more will his cheerful voice be heard at our morning roll- call, nor his joyous spirits enliven our evening camp fires.
But he fell nobly at his post, with his face to the foe. He was the best of friends and the kindest of messmates, and none will more sincerely mourn his loss than his comrades in the field.
His remains were taken to his Hime, in Prince Edward, and buried in the old family cemetery.
May the sweetest flowers bloom ever over the spot where he is laid is the sincere wish of one who loved him as a brother.
Wm. J. N.

Died, on the evening of the 26th of June, from wounds received whilst gallantly leading his command into action, Major Wm. N. Bronaugh, of the 2d Arkansas battalion, late professor of ancient and modern languages in the St. John's College, located at Little Rock, Ark.

In the death of this chivalrous and accomplished young officer the South has sustained a loss which cannot be easily repaired.
Endowed with an unusual degree of mental ligor, thoroughly educated, and furnishing the brightest evidences of future usefulness and distinctive he has thus fallen a victim to the miscreant horse who have invaded our homes and fireside and took to accomplish our subjugation.

On Sunday, the 29th of June, Leven W. Luckett, in the 23d year of his age, a member of company D, 8th Virginia regiment, from a wound received in the charge upon the enemy's batteries near Gaines's Mills on the evening of the 27th inst.

He entered the service of the Southern Confederacy fourteen months ago. This was his fifth conflict with the enemy, at all times and under all circumstances deporting himself with gallantry and intrepidity.
He has fallen a youthful martyr-- a noble sacrifice to the cause of Southern rights and independence.
